Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: Leadership needs a prompt reply to confirm details for an external partner.
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: Police have just begun to unexpectedly block the exits of the protest area, and you must immediately help coordinate a safe response.
Story: My phone buzzed insistently in my pocket as I stood at the edge of the protest, scanning the crowd for familiar faces. The police had just started blocking the exits, and panic was beginning to ripple through the group. As one of the organizers, I knew I had to act fast—coordinate a safe response, keep everyone calm, and make sure no one got hurt. But then, another vibration: a message from my manager, marked urgent. Leadership needed a prompt reply to confirm details for an external partner, and I was the point of contact. I could almost hear my colleagues’ voices in my head, reminding me of the importance of timely communication, especially with high-stakes projects. My hands shook as I toggled between the group chat for the protest and my work email, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in. I knew that whichever message I answered first, I’d be letting someone down. My heart pounded as I tried to decide where my attention belonged in this moment.
